text: Companies are leaning on their finance teams to weigh the possible benefits of generative artificial intelligence (AI) against the costs‚Äîand keep those costs in check. The stakes can feel enormous, and nobody wants to be left behind by their rivals. Companies across industries are testing generative AI to make their workforces more productive, communicate with customers, or improve financial forecasting. Companies are gauging returns using metrics such as productivity gains and employee satisfaction, as well as revenue. But the technology can also come with a multimillion-dollar price tag for companies spending money on infrastructure, staff and partnerships with software providers. Companies can pay to use proprietary models from providers such as OpenAI, or they can also build their own generative AI tools using open-source models, such as Meta‚Äôs Llama 2 AI model. Motorola is testing potential applications for generative AI using models the company purchased from software providers to summarize complex industry contracts and helping software developers with tasks such as writing first drafts of code. Airbnb‚Äôs CFO and CTO are trying to prioritize among possible experiments with generative AI to improve customer service, a critical area for the company. It is also using computer-vision models to help automatically identify photos and use machine learning to help guests find listings that match their needs. Airbnb has been leaning in to see where they can leverage AI to just make the kind of matching of problem and solution more straightforward, more efficient and get to better outcomes. Intuit is using and testing generative AI across its product lines to help answer customer questions or generate invoice reminders. Some of the AI-driven features Intuit has introduced for its customers are expected to provide the company with pricing power over time. Companies also could face additional costs if they had to switch from an AI platform that didn‚Äôt pan out, particularly if they have a high volume of contracts. But finance chiefs won‚Äôt be able to fully gauge the value of an AI tool until they give it a shot. And the return on AI could also improve with use. Software company Autodesk is also looking for possible uses of generative AI within the finance team itself. It is already applying the technology to help with forecasting and identifying patterns in customers‚Äô consumption of cloud services, which allows Autodesk to predict its own future cloud costs. As AI is more widely used across the finance team the department‚Äôs hiring costs may change. If companies can automate some of the processes that underpin the ability for those more strategic finance people to be successful, they might be hiring fewer people on an incremental basis in the long-term. #ai #aiinvestment

text: This weekend I watched the new black mirror episode "Joan is Awful" If you haven't seen it and don't want it spoiled, please keep scrolling. See I believe that those of you who truly and genuinely believe that AI is hiding your resume from humans are living on level 1 of this reality. Nothing we as recruiters can say and do to tell you the true reality will change your mind. Here is the big thing about AI within the hiring process. It's not yet AI! Not the way people think of AI! At best it's Machine Learning and at it's simplest it's automation. And to be clear automation is a small part of AI and Machine Learning. But genuinely I'm tired of this argument. If you want to believe in an AI, you do that. Anyone peddling that they can teach you how to beat the AI in the job process is... This job market is awful and people are getting scammed left and right. However, just like Annie Murphy had to break the quantum computer herself to pull out of her false reality, you too will have to do the same. Most of the time, the AI calibration is about making sure that your resume is telling the other side how you're qualified using the words that are listed in the job description. Anywhoodles, if you want real advice listen to people who don't use fear tactics. Until next time, Stay Caffeinated!

text: Last week was the first time I actually gardened on my gardening leave (photo of my lovely purple tulips). I was in 120%. The little green ‚ÄòOpen to Work‚Äô banner will soon disappear. More about that soon‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs been satisfying, exhausting and frustrating. I‚Äôm sharing my experience to improve job searching for candidates and hiring managers: 1. Lower your expectation about using LinkedIn to find a role: I know a couple of people that have found theirs here but 8/10 organisations do not reply, there‚Äôs no indication they‚Äôve read your CV, and even when you‚Äôre flagged as a ‚Äòtop applicant‚Äô, a machine is likely doing the triage. Go direct to the hiring manager and introduce yourself. If you‚Äôre advertising through LI, make sure there‚Äôs a feedback loop or don‚Äôt do it. 2. That said‚Ä¶ If you do tout ‚ÄòI‚Äôm hiring‚Äô, you‚Äôve got to follow though. Two posters I contacted about salary range or to apply directly said that they weren‚Äôt authorised to discuss and to contact HR. Fail. If a hiring manager can‚Äôt represent their role, it says everything you need to know about company bureaucracy, and kicks a big dent in a corporate brand. I‚Äôll remember the names of those firms for the wrong reasons. 3. Your network is everything, but be careful about contacting ex-colleagues you worked with a while ago. They‚Äôll see you in a box, and not one that reflects the development and experience you‚Äôve had since. One ex-boss told me they didn‚Äôt have anything for a JD I‚Äôd moved away from 12 years ago. 4.  We can debate the back to the office move, but it really does limit the talent pool. I‚Äôve worked remotely for almost eight years, and hybrid for a further seven years. I always been able to co-parent dependent children and nail my work in an international team. Commuting two hours to sit in an office and talk to (another) international team through Zoom makes no sense. Stronger culture and communication win every time over presenteeism. 5. People don‚Äôt know you exist until you put yourself in front of them. I flew to #MWC2024 , door stepped and went direct to CEOs in my sector. Not everyone was hiring. Your timing might be out. But you‚Äôll make a ton of new contacts, that will remember you for the future. 6. Your bills, your mortgage and the children you need to feed are not top of anyone‚Äôs agenda but your own. Contacts mean well when they say they‚Äôll help, but you have to hustle and keep it up. NB: Recruiters are also lovely, but unless they have a a specific role it‚Äôs unlikely they can help. 7. If you‚Äôve got the luxury of a few weeks, do some professional education. It‚Äôs productive and reflects well. Here are the big mistakes I made between 2012 (when I first tried to learn to code) and 2019.: 1. ¬†I focused on learning languages and chasing the newest tools/frameworks. text: üì¢üì¢ Call for short papers at the Trustworthy AI Workshop @ IJCAI 2024 In recent years, an overwhelming body of work has been done on fairness and robustness in machine learning (ML) models. This is expected given the increasing use of ML models to support decision-making in high-stakes applications such as mortgage lending, hiring, and diagnosis in healthcare. Trustworthy AI aims to provide an explainable, robust, and fair decision-making process. In addition, transparency and security also play a significant role in improving the adoption and impact of ML solutions. Currently, most ML models assume ideal conditions and rely on the assumption that test/clinical data comes from the same distribution of the training samples. However, this assumption is not satisfied in most real-world applications; in a clinical setting, we can find different hardware devices, diverse patient populations, or samples from unknown medical conditions. On the other hand, we need to assess potential disparities in outcomes that can be translated and exacerbated in our ML solutions. Particularly, data and models are often imported from external sources in addressing solutions in developing countries, thereby risking potential security issues. The inconsistency between the data and model with the population at hand also poses a lack of transparency and explainability in the decision-making process. This workshop aims to bring researchers, policymakers, and regulators together to discuss ways to ensure security and transparency while addressing fundamental problems in developing countries, particularly when data and models are imported and/or collected locally with less focus on ethical considerations and governance guidelines. ‚ùó Relevant topics ‚ú® Transparency, explainability, interpretability in ML models. ‚ú® Security and privacy concerns in ML models. ‚ú® Misinformation detection. Data poisoning and adversarial examples. ‚ú® Audit techniques for data and ML models. ‚ú® Fairness and exclusion studies (benchmarks and datasets). ‚ú® Evaluation for ensuring fair outcomes for all, especially underrepresented groups. ‚ú® Robustness, safety, and collective value alignment, with a specific interest in measures that support developing countries and underrepresented communities. ‚ú® Social good, participatory AI, and applications of the above principles to different domains (e.g. healthcare, loans, legal). üìú Instructions If you‚Äôre interested in presenting your work, please submit a 4-page paper (4 pages for content and 2 for references) following the IJCAI Author Kit format at https://lnkd.in/ePuQB7Sb .
